projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

revisionDesc.change: 2005-03 Apex CoVantageKeyed and coded from ProQuest page images
2005-04 Judith SiefringText and markup reviewed and edited

div.p: A CATALOGVE OF DIVERS VISIBLE PROFESSORS OF the Catholike Faith. Which sheweth, that the Roman Church hath byn (as the true Church must be) continually Visible, in all Ages since Christ. Taken out of the Appendix to the Reply of A. D. vnto M. Ant. Wotton, and M. Ioh. White Ministers.

q.p: Inquire of ancient tymes before you: remember the old dayes of your Fore-fathers: consider of euery age as they haue passed: aske your Father and he will tell you: demaund of your Ancestours, and they will declare vnto you.

div.p: Permissu Superiorum. M. DC. XIV.

div.head: TO THE READER.
div.p: GENTLE Reader, This ensuing Catalogue, hath byn greatly desyred by diuers friends to be printed alone, to the end, that when any Aduersarie of the Roman Church shall demaund (as the vse of many is to do now adayes) a visible succession of Professours of the Catholike Faith, throughout euery Age, all agreeing in one, & the self same vnity of Faith and Beliefe, from Christ his time vnto ours; thou maist easily, & without further seeking of other Authours, shew the same vnto him for his satisfactioÌ„ in this behalfe. And if he cannot shew vnto thee a like succession of Professors of his Church & Faith (as infallibly he will neuer be able to do) all agreeing in the profession of one and the same Faith and beliefe from the beginning; then hast thou good reason not only not to credit, or harken vnto him, or his Church, but vnto the Catholike, one of whose speciall Markes, is this of visible Succession, which of how great importance the same is, and euer hath byn in the coÌ„trouersy of Catholik and Protestant beliefe, I leaue to thy prudent Consideration.

cell.hi: The first Nicene Councell, hauing in it 318. Fathers vnder Pope Siluester against Arius the Heretike.
The first Constantinopolitan CouÌ„ cell, hauing in it 150. Fathers vnder Damasus Pope, against Macedonius the Heretike.

row.cell: Liberius. Liberius vvas first before Felix, and secondly after Felix.
Felix II. Liberius vvas first before Felix, and secondly after Felix.

cell.hi: The Ephesine Councell hauing in it 200. Fathers vnder Celestine Pope, against Nestorius the Heretike.

row.cell: The Calcedon Councell hauing in it 630. Fathers, vnder Leo Pope, against Eutiches the Heretike.
The second Constantinopolitane Councell, hauing in it 165â–ª Fathers, vnder Pope Vigilius, against Anthimus & Theodorus.

The third Constantinopolitane Councell, hauing in it 290. Fathers vnder Pope Agatho against the Me
â€¢ othelites.

cell.hi: The second Nicene Councell, hauing in it 350. Fathers, vnder Pope Adrian, against Imagebreakers.

row.cell: The fourth Constantinopolitane Councell, hauing in it 300. Fathers, vnder Adrian the second Pope, against Photius.

The Laterane Councell, hauing in it 113. Fathers, vnder Nicolas the second Pope, in which Berengarius the Heretike (who denyed the Reall presence of Christs body in the B. Sacrament) being conuicted, did abiure that Heresy.
The Laterane Councell, hauing in it 1285. Fathers, vnder Pope Innocentius the III. against diuers Heresies.
The Councell of Lyons hauing in it almost 1000. Fathers, vnder Pope Gregory the tenth, against the errour of the Greekes.
The Councell of Viennaâ–ª hauing in it 300. Fathers vnder Pope Clement the fifth, against divers Heresies.

cell.hi: The Councel of Florence, vnder Pope Eugenius the fourth.
The Councell of Trent, vnder Paul the third, and Pius the fourth Popes, against the Lutherans.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 100.
div.p: The Blessed Virgin Marie.

S. Iohn Baptist. S. Iohn Apostle & Euangelist, with the other Apostles and Euangelists. Martha. Mary Magdalene. S. Paul Apostle. Stephen the first Martyr. Timothy. Barnabas. Tecla. Dionysius Areopagita. Martialis. Andothers.

p.hi: Romans, Corinthians, Galathians, Ephesians, Philippians, Colossians, Thessalvnians, Hebrewes, and others dispersed through all Countreys where the Apostles and Apostolike men preached, to wit, in Italy, Spaine, France, England &c.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 200.
div.p: Ignatius. Eustachius. Hermes. Getulius. Polycarpus. Concordius. Iustinus. Eusebius. Vincentius. Pantenus. Irenaeus. Potentianus. Narcissus. Potamiena. Sophia. Spes. Fides. Charitas. Felicitas with her seauen children. Dionysius Corinth. Peregrinus. Lucius King of England. Andochiusâ–ª Agrippinus, and innumerable others.

p.hi: Many Indians conuerted by Pantenus. See Baronius his Annales, and Martyrologe.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 300.
div.p: Simplicius. Calepodius. Abdon. Sennen. Pamachius. Tiburtius. Valerianus. Verianus. Marcellinus. Dorotheus. Gordianus. Polieuctus. Potentiana. Triphon. Blasius. Maximianus. Clemens. Barbara. Agatha. Apollonia. Cyprianus. Hippolitus. Gregorius. Thaumaturg. Pontius. Laurentius. Thyrsus. Caecilia. Victorius. Polychronius. Nemesius. Olympius. Crispinus. Crispinianus. Adrianus. Eubolus. Georgius. Irene. Chronia. Pantaleon. Agnes. Iulitta. Gordius. Barlaam. Gereon with his companions. Cosmas. Damianus. Mauritius with the Thebean Legion. and others without number.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 400.
div.p:
Domnus with 2000. Martyrs. Lucianus. Theodorus. Paulus the first Eremite. Milles. Iacobus Nisibitanus. Spiridion. Macarius. Nicolaus. Helene mother to Constantine. Constantine Emperour, by whose meanes Christian Religion did wonderfully flourish. Marcus Arethusius. Nicetas. Theodorus. Antonius. Hilarion. Artenus. Athanasius. Martyrius. Paulus Constantinop. Hilarius. Martianus.
Pachomius. Gregorius Nazianz. Ephreem. Didimus. Macarius. Nicetius. Basilius. Pacianus. Mutius. Prudentius. Ambrosius. Hieronymus. Epiphanius. Brixius. Cyrillus Hierosolym. Euphrasia. Blesilla. Amphilochius.

p.hi: The conuerted Dacians, Getes, Bess â€¢â€¢ es, and Scythians, Morins, and Neruians, of whome Paulinus writeth. The Armenians, and Huns, and those troupes of Monkes of India, Persia, Aethiopia, of which S. Hierome writeth, and infinite others.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 500.
div.p: Seuerinus. Tigrius. Exuperius. Eutropius. Ioannes Chrysostom. Paulinus. Mauritius. Augustinus. Maximus. Sisimus. Vincentius Lyrin. Iacobus Persa. Alexius. Cyrillus Alexandrinus. Vrsula with 11000. Virgins. Prosper. Honoratus. Rusticus. Palladius. Germanus. Bonifacius. Euthymius. Simeon Stelites. Chrysologus. Patricius. G â€¢ minianus. Proclus. Remigius. Vedastus. Albinus. Eugenius. Vigilius. Fulgentius. Boetius Epiphanius Ticinensis. Nilus. Seuerinus. Theodosius Abbas.
The Scots conuerted by Palladius. The French conuerted by Remigius and Vedastus. 4979. Martyres and Confessors of Africa, and many others.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 600.
div.p:
Gerardus. Genouefa. Columbus. Oportuna. Germanus Parisiensis. Maria Aegyptiaca. Brigitta. Simeon Salus. Leander. Benedictus Institutor of the Order of Benedictine Monkes. Rupertus. Maurus. Placidus. Arnulphus. Launomarus. Radegundis. Leonardus. Hospitius. Gallus. Columbanus. Ioannes Clymacus. Goar. Ermingildus. Isaac. Felix. Quiriacus. Fortunatus. Tetricus. Agricola. Auitus. Bonifacius. Cassius. Victor. Cerbo â€¢ ius. Crotildis. Dacius. Eleutherius. â€¢ irminus. Lantus. Nicetius. Praetextatus. Quintianus. Euphronius. Eusychius. Gregorius Turonensis. Medardus. Dalmatius. Paternus
Mellitus. Sabbas, and others.
Augustine the Monke who sent by Pope Gregory conuerted England. The Northern Picts, the Gothes, the Bauarians, Barbaricians, and Burgundians were conuerted in this age.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 700.
div.p: Anastasius Persa. Walburga. Attala. Eustasius. Ioannes E â€¢ eemosynarius. Isidorus. Claudius Bizunt. Theodorus. Arnulphus. Aldegund. Eligius. Seuerus. Caesarius. Bauo. Maximus. Trudo. Oswaldus. Audoenus. Lambertus. Gaugericus. Anhelmus. Betulphus. Berta. Cunibertus. Aidanus. Cuthbertus. â€¢ ulranus. Marinus. Bercarins. Eugenius. The two Ewaldies. Andonius. Damianus Tiemensis. Kilianns. Ioannes Bergomensis. Willebrordus. Aldagisus. Ceadda. Maxellendis. Proiectus. Paulinus. Wikfridus. Edilburga. Leodigarius. Suibertus. Walericus Nicetius. Vltanus, and others

p.hi: The Flemings conuerted by Eligius. The VVestphalians conuerted by the two Ewaldies. The people of
Franconia concuerted by Kilianus. Multitudes of Spaniards conuerted by Andonius. The Frizians conuerted by VVillebrord.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 800.
div.p: Venerable Bede. Bonitus. Grimoaldus. Guthlacus. Ioannes Damascenus. Germanus. W â€¢ nocus. Hermingildis. Bonifacins. Sebaldus. Piectu â€¢ dis. Wandergilsus. Lioba. Iodocus. Pirminus. Odilia. Gertrudis. Hubertus. A â€¢ gilolphus. Lullus. Butchardus. Rigobertus. Gangulphus. Gudula & others.

The Hassus, Thuringians, Erphordians, and Cattians conuerted by Boniface the English Monke. The Lombards conuerted by Sebaldus. The Iewes of the ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ Berithum being conuerted by the bleeding of a Crucifix which was ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ by them contumeliously, the bloud whereof cured al â€¢ diseases, a Crantzius testifieth in Metropol l.
â€¢
c. 9â–ª The two Saxon Dukes, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ and Albion conuerted by a miraculous sight seene by VVi â€¢ k â€¢ ndu â€¢ , to â€¢ it, a faire child descending from the Priests hands into the mouth of them that receiued the holy Sacrament.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 900.
div.p: Sabinus. Ansgratius. Ludgerus. Gerfridus. Geroldus. Ioannicius. Ida. Nicetas. Monolphus. Withgungus. Adelradus. Meruardus. Rumoldus. Ansgarus. Rembertus. Swithinus. Atalphus. Se â€¢ inandus, and others.

p.hi: The Danes and Swethens conuerted by Ansgratius. The Bulgarians conuerted by Ioannicius. The Rugians conuerted by the Monkes of Corbeia. The Morauians conuerted by VVithgungus. The Russites conuerted by a Priest sent by the Emperour Basilius.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 1000.
div.p:
Odo Cluniacensis. Wenceslaus. Adalricus. Bruno Coloniensis. Guibertus Maiolus.
Dunstanus. Romoaldus. Elphegus. Adelheides. Wolfgangus. Poppo. Berualdus. Adelbertus. Aegidius Tusculanus, and others.

p.hi: The Polonians conuerted by Aegidius Tusculanus sent by Pope Iohn the XIII. The Sclauonians conuerted by Adelbert. The Hungarians conuerted by another Adelbert.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 1100.
div.p:
Odilo Cluniacensis.. Henricus II. the Emperour. Kunegundis. Colomanus. Petrus
Damianus. Oddas. Simeon the Eremite. Brado. Dominicus Loricatus. Gothardus. Edouardus. Wigbertus. Lantfrancus. Gerardus Gandauens. Anselmus. Stanislaus. Aswerus. Godfridus Ambianens. Arnulphus Suesson. Iuo. Bruno Carthusian. Hugo Cluniacensis. Hugo Grationopol. and others.

p.hi: The Vindicians, and multitudes of Prussians conuerted in this age.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 1200.
div.p:
Agnes Romana. Noribertus. Malachias. Bernardus Abb. Gulielmus Duke, and after Eremite. Gerardus. Hildegardis.
Thomas Cantuariensis. Hugo Lincolniensis, and others.

p.hi: The Pomeranians and Noruegians conuerted by Nicolas the English Monke, who after was made Pope, called Adrian the fourth.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 1300.
div.p: Dominicus Institutour of the Order of Dominican Fryars. Franciscus Institutour of the Order of the Franciscan Fryars. Maria de Oegne. Christina Mirabilis. Engelbertus Coloniensis. Petrus Mediolan. Luitgardis. Elizabeth Lan â€¢ grau. Antonius Paduan. Gulielmus Bononiensis. Hiacynthus. Alexander de Hales. Thomas Aquinas. Bonauentura. Nicolaus Nouesiensis. Heduigis. Medardes. Nicolaus Tolentinas. Irmgardis. Mechtildis. Gertrudis. Angela de Fulgineo, and others.

p.hi: The Liuonians conuerted by Medardes. The Lituanians conuerted by the Knights of S. Mary. The
Emperour Cassanes, with innumerable Tartarians conuerted in this age.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 1400.
div.p: Iuo Iurisconsultus. Rochus. Christina Sumlensis. Venturinus Bergomensis. Gertrudis ab Oesten. Godfridus Eptingensis. Henricus Suso. Catharina Senensis. Albertus Allobrog. Andreas Fesulanus. Gerardus Groet, and others.

p.hi: Azatines Emperour of the Turkes, the Iles of Canaries, the reuolted Lituanians, the Cunians, the Bosnians, the Lipnensians, the Patrinians, and other Sclauonian Nations conuerted by meanes of Pope Clement the sixt, and Lewis King of Hungary.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 1500.
div.p: Colecta. Vincentius Valentinus. Bernardinus Senensis. Ioannes Capistranus. Laurentius Iustinianus. Antoninus Florentinus. Didacus ab Ascala. Andreas Chias. Maria Toletan â€¢ . Dominicus Pisciensis. Margarita Rauenatensis. Nicolaus the Bremite. Iacobus Picenus. Iacobus Alemannus. Columba Reatin. IoaÌ„na Roderignsia. Osanna Mantuana, and others.

p.hi: The Gamogetians. The people of the Kingdomes of Betonine, Guinaea, Angola, and Congo conuerted in this age.

div.head: Vnto the yeare 1600.
div.p:
Catharina Genuensis. Franciscus Ã Paula. Andreas ex Olmo. Franciscus Ximenaeus. Gentilis Rauenatensis. Martinus Valentinus. Stephanus Soncinas. Ignatius Loyola Institutour of the Society of Iesus. Franciscus Xauerius. Felix Capucinus. Stanislaus Kostka. Ioannes de S. Francisco.
Carolus Boromaeus. Antonius Pestana. Alexander Capocchius. Nicolaus Fictor. Aloysius Bertrandus. Edmundus Campianus. Philippus Nereus. Antonia Romana. Aloysius Gonzaga. Caesar Baronius. Gulielmus Alanus. Gregorius de Valentia. Thomas Stapletonus. Robertus Bellarminus, Robertus Personius, and infinite others.

p.hi: As in Italy, France, England, Spaine, Germany, Polonia, and other Christian Countryes: besides innumerable people in the Indies, Iaponta, China, Brasilia, and other places lately conuerted to the Faith, by Religious men of the Roman Faith.

div.head: AN ADVERTISEMENT concerning the former Catalogue.
div.p: I Would haue thee aduertised (Gentle Reader) that in this Catalogue, I haue set downe the Names of all the chiefe Pastours, as being the principall members of the visible Militant Church, with obseruation of the yeare or time, and such order of succession, as I could find in those Authors, which I had at hand.

Likewise I haue set downe, the names of some few other Professours, liuing in, or neere those seuerall ages, in which I haue placed them: but in this I haue not byn so curious, either to name all which are knowne, or which my selfe know to haue bene; or to set downe any precise yeare, or orderly succession of their being; but haue contented my self to name only a few in euery age, and this without specifying the particuler yeare, in which they flourished, or obseruing any exact order, in which they succeeded one another.

Thirdly, I haue set downe some principall Councells, or Assemblies of the Pastors,
and Doctours of the Church, leauing out many others, which I might haue set downe. The reason why on the one side, I haue set downe these particulers, is, that it may euidently appeare, that the Catholike Roman Church hath bene continually Visible, in euery Age, as the true Church must, and ought to be.

On the other side, the reason why I haue omitted so many other particulers, is, partly that I may not be too tedious to my Reader; and partly that I may not seeme to exact vnreasonable paynes to be taken by our Aduersaryes, when a like Catalogue shal be required of theÌ„, of the names of like visible Professours of their ProtestaÌ„t Church & beliefe throughout euery age: which whiles they do not (as indeed they cannot) I may boldly say with old Irenaeus, Iren. l. 1. c. 3.

q.p: That by only bringing forth that Tradition and Religion, which the greatest, and most ancient, and to all men manifest, I say, the Church of Rome, founded and erected by the two most glorious Apostles S. Peter & S. Paul, receiued of them, and by succession of Bishops, hath brought vnto our time; we do counfound all those, which howsoeuer, either by vaine pleasing of themselues, or vaine glory, or by blindnes and peruerse iudgment, do make erroneous decoctions.

div.p:
And this I may the better vrge, because
(as the same Irenaeus affirmeth)

q.p: there is in the Roman Church a more powerfull principality, by reason wherof, it is necessary for euery Church, that is, for all Christians throughout the whole world, to haue recourse vnto it &c.

div.p: If any be desyrous to see more of this matter, let him peruse the Reply it selfe (out of which this Catalogue is taken) and the Treatise of Faith, newly set forth by the same Author.
